review_title: Great atmosphere in the Biology department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Little Rock, AR
pros: Great atmosphere, tutoring on site for each subject, approachable professors for the most part, grants and competitions were regularly emailed to students to inform them of upcoming opportunities, the pay for graduate assistantships wasn't bad considering they paid for our tuition as well, and my boss was pretty awesome.
cons: the tuition is too much and became more expensive each year, the campus is spaced to far apart, the campus is in a bad neighborhood, some staff members are burnt out because of the bad students that have ruined it for the rest of us, some of the students didn't want to do their work which was frustrating as a lab instructor, the tuition may not have been bad but it was still hard to live on

job_title: IT Consultant in Jonesboro, AR
pros: You can bring APERS retirement into the university, I was non-contributory, so they paid almost $9000 into my retirement each year; Health Insurance and other types of insurance is very reasonable, although the Co-pay and OOP has increased a lot; They provide Life Insurance up to $50K I believe.  You have to pay if you want extra, but it's not much.  If non-classified employee, which this position is, you get 4 weeks of vacation and 22 days sick.  They dismiss you with pay on icy/treacherous days or let you go home early.  If Little Rock Schools dismiss, then they dismiss.
cons: You have to walk a long way to campus if you don't pay for parking.  If you want up closer in the parking lots surrounding buildings, then you have to pay about $16 a paycheck or a month for that.  Spots may not come available immediately.  You may have to wait a bit for one.

review_title: Wonderfully diverse campus with a driven student body.
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Little Rock, AR
pros: My particular department is fantastic. The faculty is warm, friendly, and encouraging. I cannot speak to all other departments but I have thoroughly enjoyed it so far. The students are interesting, to say the least, and I have LOVED the integrated, diverse student body. The focus on teaching is refreshing but there is still the capacity to pursue research and publication. I only give it a neutral rating because I've only been here a very brief period of time. Perhaps I will review again at the end of my first semester.
cons: HR has some serious hiccups. The administration at this university leaves something to be desired, especially when you consider the relatively small size of the student body and employee rosters. However, my chair spend countless hours fighting to get things made right for me. They just have some kinks that ought to be worked out; it makes the university look a bit inept.

review_title: A diverse student body with caring faculty but poor administration puts UALR's future at risk.
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Little Rock, AR
pros: Diverse student population and caring faculty.
cons: Terrible administration; teachers are expected to go FAR above and beyond what would be expected of them at other colleges/universities for a far lesser salary. Few chances for raises or promotions as departments are small and budgets are tight. If you do get in, expect to stay around the same pay throughout the length of your career. Campus is also a bit sketchy. There are armed robberies during school hours and the Big Lots parking lot where the majority of people park is dirty and somewhat dangerous if walking there after hours. Just be aware of your surroundings and don't flaunt any valuables.

review_title: Good place to gain varied experience for self motivated 1st job seekers
job_title: Research Associate in Little Rock, AR
pros:
Gain experience doing lots of different tasks.
Work to train future generations of leaders.
Good entertainment, retirement and health benefits.
cons:
Not a lot of room for upward mobility.  This makes the institution a place that feels more like a stepping stone than a place to build a successful career.
Lack of access to well trained support staff.
Resources are spread very thin which can make it hard to invest in necessary human and physical infrastructure improvements.
Institutional relationship is not strong with the local city government or business sector.

job_title: Research Associate in Little Rock, AR
pros: Good benefits. Includes health, dental, retirement and plenty of vacations.
cons: No professional growth in this university. The salary is very low and can stay the same forever. The amount of work performed does not matter to get promotion or salary hike. You have to be a favorite to get it. This is a place for lazy people only. The nanocenter here do meaningless research and the skills acquired here is useless to find a job anywhere. They just use fantastic researchers to produce papers for their big boss. There is no focus and one has to work on various projects and ones interest does not matter. There is no in-depth study and research, which eventually kills a young researcher career. Don't waste your time, value and career by working in this hopeless place.

review_title: Dysfunctional Campus from Top to Bottom
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Little Rock, AR
pros: None. I received a salary with benefits. But that's the bare minimum you should be getting from a job.
cons: Salary far below market value. Completely impersonal faculty relationships and very little upper administrative interest/interaction. Students are far below the quality that should be allowed in a four-year university. Grade inflation is rampant. Support staff is inept, from the HR department that has no idea what it's doing to the Facilities staff, who don't think it's their job to do ANYTHING within their job description. Parking is a major problem on campus. The campus location is in a high-crime, low-income part of the city - a student was kidnapped and murdered from across the street several years ago. The campus is ugly and laid out with no logic - most of the buildings look like they were used for prisoner torture in the Soviet Union during the Cold War.

review_title: Not a great place to work if you want to make a lot of money or advance in your career but the benefits are nice.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: Tuition discount, nice co-workers, decent facilities available to employees. The breakfast and lunch summer benefits are a positive step. Also the lunch truck programs from time to time are nice.
cons: Managers have little to no personnel training. Many do not have appropriate professional academic credentials for business areas they support. Favoritism and nepotism in hiring and promotion is rampant.

review_title: Great research opportunities for PhD candidates
job_title: Research Assistant in Little Rock, AR
pros: Lots of opportunities to publish papers and  to gain teaching and research experience. Helpful teachers and researchers across the campus if you are running a collaborative research. Available funds for publishing conference papers up to $500 each semester on a first come first serve basis.
cons: Registration times are always stressful, employee handbook keeps changing constantly, it is hard to follow and not very easy to understand the decisions. The upper management can be considered as greedy but if you are contacting the right person they are always willing to help.

review_title: Not the best, not the worst.
job_title: Adjunct in Little Rock, AR
pros: Considering that you will end up working for about $4 an hour at 2k per 40 students per semester... Not many pros. You get paid $50 per student per semester, basically. You will work more than 20 hours per week just to keep up with emails, drama, and confusion from students who were never prepared to do collegiate work.
cons: Poorly prepared and high-maintenance students, fast food franchise work would pay better with fewer hours due to the time intensive needs of students who aren't prepared/able to do collegiate-level work. You can't give assignments and then grade, you will spend hours explaining extraordinarily simple and basic concepts to students who are functioning at perhaps a sixth or seventh-grade educational level.

job_title: Student Worker in Little Rock, AR
pros: The hours are flexible. The supervisors are willing to negotiate pay outside of the UALR Works guidelines. All of the supervisors are very nice and accommodating.
cons: The hours can be restricted to basic business hours during the week (8AM-5PM) which can make it difficult to get a lot of hours due to personal class schedules.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Little Rock, AR
pros: GA positions are meant to help the student by providing an income while attending classes.
cons: The work load can be so heavy that a regular office job would be a lot easier to handle when trying to keep up with coursework, too.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Little Rock, AR
pros: If you want to work here this is one of the Nicest, easiest traffic, and  cool place. Affordable city for a poor graduate student.
